lg.l: I stood upon a narrow ledge of earth,
Cunningly fashioned by the hand of man,
Into a road, Road. A steep road over the Remutaka Range, which divides Wellington from the plains of the Wairarapa, had first been created in the 1840s. which like a serpent trailed,
And wound along in sinuous winding track,
Now straight as arrow thrown, now shrinking darkly
Into a narrow bend as tho’ in fear. Again
‘Twould forward straightly run, higher and higher,
Hugging the side of that stupendous hill.
I stood upon the ledge—and sloping down
Beneath my feet, forests of trees and shrubs
And towering fern, and stately cabbage-tree,
And everywhere the wild white native flowers
In rich profusion grew. Berries of Rata plant,
Whose scarlet beauty mingled with the dark
And glossy green of its imperial tree,
Glistened and lit the darkness of the whole.
Sloped in one vast descent hundreds of feet,
Until the verdure met the river bed
And kissed its waters.
Upwards then arose
Upon the further side, one long unbroken chain,
Of dark and mighty trees, rising to Heaven’s dome,
And stretching miles away. A living range
Of undulating verdure, clothed in every shade
Of rare and choicest green.
The lustrous tints
Of pale pure colour on the younger leaves,
Through which the sun’s reflected light appeared
Making them shine transparent. Then the shade
Of older leaflets. That bright middle tint,
The which is seen upon the grass in spring
After the rain hath fall’n. Again the sombre green
Upon the perfectly developed leaves,
Mingled together, in rich beauty forming
One vast and splendid panorama
Radiant in tinted loveliness, and bearing
On it the impress of the hand of God.
As mine eye travelled on, I marked where man
With devastating hand had marred the glory
Of this fair wooded scene. Thousands of trees
Threw up their blackened arms to Heaven’s vault,
Like ghastly demons in their fell despair
Demanding vengeance on destroying man.
I stood upon that narrow ledge, and looked,
Until my spirit left its tenement,
Roaming far, far away over the scene,
Going beyond all space to commune with
Another spirit watching there for mine.
The spirit said to mine “cast down thine eyes
Upon the works of God beneath thy feet;
Thou standest there upon the ledge of rock
A speck, an atom ‘midst His wondrous works.
Can’st thou with head uplifted and erect,
Not feel the influence of the scene before thee?”
Thus did the spirit speak to me in space,
And thus I answered him—
“Oh beauteous spirit
The wondrous grandeur of the scene before me
Hath so uplifted me out of myself,
That my charm’d soul hath left its dwelling-place
Briefly to commune in the spirit land.”
I stand with folded hands upon my breast,
With rapt uplifted eyes, silently breathing
My heart’s deep adoration to the Giver
And Maker of such great and glorious works.
I see in every leaf, in every stem,
In every trailing flower upon the scene,
His mighty Majesty, His wondrous love.
Oh! Spirit, bear upon Thy pinion bright
The adoration of His servant here,
And lay it humbly at its Maker’s feet.
My soul came back. Still on the ledge I stood,
A speck on Rimatuka’s [sic] rocky height,
Down at my feet the flowers and verdure lay
In silent loveliness. Above my head
The beetling crag frowned down with aspect drear.
Slowly my sense returned—my heart o’ercharged
With an excess of joy, and painéd feeling;
Joy; for the glorious vision of that mountain;
Pain; for the thought that in a world so fair,
So all replete with perfectness of form,
The demon sin, should reign and rule supreme.
